issues.description: Task 10 in the problem statement explicitly asks for the count of hiking paths in a column named `Menge`, but the solution implementation names the column `Anzahl` (COUNT(*) as Anzahl). This column-name mismatch between problem specification and solution will likely cause automatic checks (and students' expectations) to fail because the expected column header differs.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the column alias in solution_repository/aufgabe10.sql to match the problem statement. For example: SELECT gemeindeschluessel, COUNT(*) AS Menge FROM Wanderweg_zu_Gemeinde GROUP BY gemeindeschluessel ORDER BY Menge DESC. Ensure the alias exactly matches `Menge` so automated checks and students' expectations align.

issues.description: The solution files use inconsistent capitalization for the Gemeinde table: aufgabe04.sql uses `gemeinde` (lowercase) while other solution files (and the problem text) refer to `Gemeinde` (capitalized). On case-sensitive SQL systems, this inconsistency can cause queries to fail or confuse students about the correct table name.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the table identifier across artifacts. Update solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql to use the same capitalization as the problem statement (e.g., FROM Gemeinde). Ensure all solution and template files use the exact same table name spelling/capitalization so students and automated tests see a consistent schema.

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires the count of Wanderwege per municipality to be output in a column named `Menge`, but the solution uses the alias `Anzahl` (SELECT gemeindeschluessel, COUNT(*) as Anzahl). This is an identifier naming mismatch for the expected output column and will cause confusion / grader mismatches because students (and tests) are instructed to produce a column named `Menge`.
issues.suggested_fix: In solution_repository/aufgabe10.sql rename the alias to the required column name. Example: SELECT gemeindeschluessel, COUNT(*) AS Menge FROM Wanderweg_zu_Gemeinde GROUP BY gemeindeschluessel ORDER BY Menge DESC.

issues.description: The problem text and other solution files refer to the Gemeinde table with the identifier `Gemeinde` (capitalized), but solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql uses `gemeinde` (lowercase) in the FROM clause. Although many SQL engines are case-insensitive for unquoted identifiers, this inconsistent capitalization across artifacts can create unnecessary confusion for students mapping the problem description to the implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a consistent table identifier across artifacts. Either change solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql to FROM Gemeinde or standardize all references to lowercase if that matches the canonical DB schema. For clarity for students, prefer matching the table name casing used throughout the problem statement (FROM Gemeinde).
